newsitem.title: TAJIKISTAN: Tajik government frees seven rebel fighters.
newsitem.headline: Tajik government frees seven rebel fighters.

text.p: The Tajik government has released seven members of the armed Islamist opposition captured in the former Soviet republic's civil war, officials said on Thursday.

"This was a gesture of goodwill," said Zafar Ikromov, a Tajik government representative on a United Nations-sponsored commission on prisoners. The men were released on Wednesday evening in a region east of the capital Dushanbe.
"The seven former anti-government fighters have already been brought to the Garm region and handed over to local opposition field commanders," Ikromov told Reuters.

Last month, Tajik President Imomali Rakhmonov and opposition leader Sayid Abdullo Nuri agreed a ceasefire at talks aimed at ending the conflict which has killed tens of thousands of people in the last four years.
The ceasefire appears to be holding and the government has released 13 prisoners since December.
But the opposition says it has released 111 government servicemen in similar gestures over the same period, and that more than 600 of its fighters are languishing in government prisons.
For its part, the government says 300 of its servicemen are still held hostage in the country's central Tavildara region alone.
